column4: how would I tell my Ubuntu to start vncserver (Xvnc) instead of X when booting up?
if you want a 'hidden' vnc session  thats not the current desktop. You can install/run some of the 'vncserver' servers such as tightvnc.
I want it to start the vncserver in place of the normal desktop. The computer is to be used via VNC only.
theres 2 ways to do vnc.. Share/show the current desktop OR have a hidden vnc session thats NOT visiable from the local machine.
if you want you could set up gnome to auto-login and start  the gnome vnc feature.
I tried vino but it has problems when running headless
sound  like you want to use a 'normal' vncserver then. There are guides on making vnc auto spawn as needed when you connect via a vnc client also.
they can spawn via inetd I recall. With the right setup
you are not understanding how vnc works. Since you are 'headless' you dont want to use Xvnc or X11vnc. You want a normal 'vncserver'
you could  ssh in, start 'vncserver' then connect via any vnc client..   its that easy. Once ya get vnc going.
can I connect to an existing, running session with that?
depends on how you launch.  an existing running VNC SESSIOn.. yes...
headless means you wont have an X session going. Just vnc sessions.
ok, that's an error in my part then, I thought headless just meant running without a monitor
and with no monitor you cant see a local X session...
so theres no need to start up X or gdm. Peronally i found 'headless' caused to many problems.

basically I just want something like Microsoft's Remote Desktop: computer boots, logs in automatically, starts programs. I connect later and see that desktop with the programs running and can control them
you can set up vncserver to do that.
and you couls start the proper vncserver from rc.local
